section.title: Gist of Exponential Functions
section.p: In this lesson we learn about a family of functions called exponential. Just like linear functions, exponentials have their or own distinct numerical patterns, unique graphs and general formulas.

subsection.title: Exponential Patterns in Data
subsection.p: When looking at data, linear functions will have a pattern of adding the same number repeatedly (a positive or negative constant) for constant changes in input. This leads to the fact that linear functions have constant rate of change (slope).

subsection.p: Notice that as you move along the x-axis, each graph tends to drop closer and closer to the x-axis. The decreasing exponential approaches the x-axis as you move to the right while the increasing exponential approaches the x-axis as you move to the left.
In fact, the farther you move right or left, the closer each graph gets to the x-axis. In truth neither graph will never reach the x-axis.
The x-axis is the horizontal line y = 0 and the graphs are tending towards y = 0 as the inputs move to the right or left.
We say that the x-axis is a horizontal asymptotehorizontal asymptote with equation y = 0. It means that the graph is getting closer and closer to the x-axis in at least one direction.

subsection.title: General Form of Exponential Formulas
subsection.p: Patterns for linear and exponential models are found in language too. For instance the statement, A worker makes \$ 15 per hour is giving us information about a linear pattern. The statement indicates that for each hour that passes the worker adds \$ 15 to their earnings.
On the other hand if the worker has a salary increase of 15 \% each year it means their earnings are multiplied by 1.15 each year.
By counting how many times we add or how many times we multiply, we can interpret a pattern in language into a math pattern, usually called a formula.
The shape or form of linear and exponential formulas are unique. They each have their own characteristics.
Linear formulas look like f(x) = mx + b
While the formula for an exponential function may look likef(x) = ab^{x} or f(x)=ae^{kx}
Where ab^{x} is called the discrete form of the exponential and ae^{kx} is called the continuous form.

example.p: In the linear function f(x)=mx+b the x is a counter. It counts how many times the number m is repeatedly added.

If a car is traveling at 50 miles per hour, then we can write a linear equation to calculate the distance the car travels as a function of time, x hours. f(x)=50x means that each hour we add another 50 miles to the distance traveled by the car. After 6 hours of driving, the vehicle has covered f(6)=50+50+50+50+50+50=50*6=300 300 miles.

subsection.p: The reason there are at least two forms of the exponential formula is there are at least two ways to derive or create an exponential model.
In practice, when we observe and measure a constant percent change we typically use the information collected to write formula directly. The result is the discrete form of the exponential formula.

example.title: Discrete Exponential Formula: ab^{x}
example.p: We can measure the increase in a population over a period of time and directly apply our findings into a discrete exponential equation to model the population growth.

p.em: A population of 500 grows by 8 \% every 10 years.

example.p: Notice how we went from an observation about the population growth directly to an equation without any algebra. We literally translated information from one language, English, to another, Math.
With one algebra step we can get an equation to model the annual percent increase.

In this example a=500 is the initial size of the population when the measuring began and b \approx 1.007726 is the annual growth factor (i.e. the number that is multiplied repeatedly) representing an annual percent growth of about 0.7726 \% each year.

subsection.p: Another way to arrive at an exponential model is through higher level calculus called differential equations. Of course we will not get too far into this subject, but here is a tiny little glimpse.

example.title: Continuous Exponential Formula: ae^{kx}

p.em: The rate of growth of a population is proportional to the size of the population. The bigger a population is, the faster it grows.

example.p: In calculus this simple statement looks like \frac{dP}{dx}=kP where x measures time, like years, and \frac{dP}{dx} is called the instantaneous rate of change. It is similar to the average rate of change \frac{\Delta P}{\Delta x} we study in this course.
This equation can be solved using calculus, but instead of the solution being a number like x=7 the solution is another formula.
Specifically, the solution is P(x)=ae^{kx}

As a scientist or engineer, if your solution to a differential equation is P(x)=300e^{0.007726x} you must recognize the solution is the continuous form of exponential growth. You should know the equation is stating an initial population size of 300 and a continuous annual growth of 0.7726 \%.

But, most importantly, you have to know the continuous 0.7726 \% growth is NOT the actual growth of the population. We have to turn the continuous information into its discrete equivalent in order to get practical use from the solution.
b=e^{0.007726} \approx 1.007756 This represents an actual annual percent growth of about 0.7756 \%.
